One hundred and eighty-seven years have
nearly elapsed since Derrick Won Hoogens-
perg landed at the westernmost point OF
Nantucket Island. He was fresh from the
region OF dykes and bitches, and was seek
ipp the goods and chattes of a rich uncle re-
Gently defunct at Ncwe Amsterdam. The
shin in which Derrick had taken passage,
driven to the eastward of her proper track,
and becalmed, Law so near the land, that he
was fain to 20 on shore in the yawl, and be-
hold for the first time sample of the new
world. He had scarcely disembarked, when
twenty or thirty young and halt tanned lndl-
ans. living concealed to his view on the sun
ny dec!iyity of sandy knoll, happened to
let forth broad horse laugh (at their own
Jokes doubtless, after the manner OF more
civilized benes) which startled his less ad-
yenturous comrades, who had not yet land
ed, that they pushed off leaving poor Derrick
utterly astounded, up to his knees in sea-
weed and conch shells.


Recovering from his amazement, Derrick
perceived himself deserted, and instructive
ly delivered most piercing yell OF suppli-
cation towards the treachereus boats crew,
now rowing furiously for the heavy bark,
that lolled lazily upon the drowsy deep like
drowned fly in bowl OF Perrldge. At the
sound OF tnIS SlTa'lSC outCiy, wv oV'" h'
voluntarily sprung up, and beheld round
squat figure waddlng violently along the
beach, clad in short blue coat half covered
with monstrous pearl buttons, long scarlet
vest parted at the neither extremity small
clothes of brown velvet, and boots of uni
form circumference, something similar to
the leathern buckets used by our mod
ern firemen. Both arms were swinging
with prodigious gyration; at the end OF one
appeared hellow hemisphere OF drab col.
ored felt, the broad rim of which was made
to vibrate to and fro in desperate signiiica-
ton of terror and dependency. From the
rear of his bare head, piotuberated cylin'
drical mass of hair. resembling huge car
rot. swathed in casing of ropeyarns--anc
amidst the contortions OF the body to which
| it was attached. this silcious appendagt
played up and down like the pump-brak'
OF a laundering Westindiaman.

Here lie walks with us no more

death!

MEMORANDA,

previously seen, and been familiar with,
some individuals of the paler species Of our
race; but the figure before them was nov

which their constitutional gra yity could not
altogether withstand. They looked again
and again at the rotund lump of humanity
hounderng amid the oozy retirement of
fast receding tide--and as they contrasted
his awkward struggles with their own agil
'ity, his shapeess obesity of frame with their
own Apollonian limbs, considering also the

hooted and roared with renewed exertion
Some screamed in prolonged and hideous

At length, weared with these roistering

dation. Decming their outrageous capering

Of soft mud-aIonve whose surface naught
Of his person remained but visage, arms. and
! abdomen. His visters halted upon the more

more of curiosity than Indignation. They

an animal. they would sooner by far dine
upon Holsters and pumpkins.


But Derrick waxed resolute, and began,

ued to approximate, and coming within

! Here the exhausted victim sunk into a

he is not miserable, though the sacrifice is
made. He is not miserable, because the
sacrifice has given new pleasure to his
heart. 1t may be the only pleasure left him
to expcrence--but it is enough to reward


him for all he has relinqnlshcd-'tis enough
to Gid adversitv, soothe sickness, to assuage
sorrow, 10 soften slavery, and even to- il'ume
the darkness of the prison-house. They
too, then, are selfish who sacrifice their own
pleasure to the happiness of friend. Aud
Love how selfish is Love Nor only those
who are swaycd by the passion alone, but he
who by the sentiment i'll all its purity ina
giuc they are governed. The loyer relin-
quishes the object Of bis affections, when R.
knows that by so doing he may keep from
her the sorrow OF the suffering which might
otherwise attend her. This gratiIies his
feelings, for in her peace he finds his own,
and her misery will bring sorrow to his own
heart. And even DevOtinn--fcrvcnt as II
may be, is assaicd by Scliishness. Were
there no hereafter. would the de, ,otion be
righteous Were there no future punish
ment, would we abstain from evil: Aud
were there no reward in future state, how
few would take up the cross and deal Justly
with all, SYLVIA.

full articles.headline:
From the Nantucket Inquirer.
THE DUTC1a EMIGRANT.
full articles.article:
One hundred and eighty-seven years have
nearly elapsed since Derrick Won Hoogens-
perg landed at the westernmost point OF
Nantucket Island. He was fresh from the
region OF dykes and bitches, and was seek
ipp the goods and chattes of a rich uncle re-
Gently defunct at Ncwe Amsterdam. The
shin in which Derrick had taken passage,
driven to the eastward of her proper track,
and becalmed, Law so near the land, that he
was fain to 20 on shore in the yawl, and be-
hold for the first time sample of the new
world. He had scarcely disembarked, when
twenty or thirty young and halt tanned lndl-
ans. living concealed to his view on the sun
ny dec!iyity of sandy knoll, happened to
let forth broad horse laugh (at their own
Jokes doubtless, after the manner OF more
civilized benes) which startled his less ad-
yenturous comrades, who had not yet land
ed, that they pushed off leaving poor Derrick
utterly astounded, up to his knees in sea-
weed and conch shells.


Recovering from his amazement, Derrick
perceived himself deserted, and instructive
ly delivered most piercing yell OF suppli-
cation towards the treachereus boats crew,
now rowing furiously for the heavy bark,
that lolled lazily upon the drowsy deep like
drowned fly in bowl OF Perrldge. At the
sound OF tnIS SlTa'lSC outCiy, wv oV'" h'
voluntarily sprung up, and beheld round
squat figure waddlng violently along the
beach, clad in short blue coat half covered
with monstrous pearl buttons, long scarlet
vest parted at the neither extremity small
clothes of brown velvet, and boots of uni
form circumference, something similar to
the leathern buckets used by our mod
ern firemen. Both arms were swinging
with prodigious gyration; at the end OF one
appeared hellow hemisphere OF drab col.
ored felt, the broad rim of which was made
to vibrate to and fro in desperate signiiica-
ton of terror and dependency. From the
rear of his bare head, piotuberated cylin'
drical mass of hair. resembling huge car
rot. swathed in casing of ropeyarns--anc
amidst the contortions OF the body to which
| it was attached. this silcious appendagt
played up and down like the pump-brak'
OF a laundering Westindiaman.


| Moved at this grotesque spectacle, the Q
verioyed barbarians cracked the air will
unruly descriptions of merrinent, and ahsp

full articles.headline: FUGITIVE THOUGHTS.
full articles.article:
We are all selfish. 10 the heartles mer-
%nary who spares not penny for the rellef
o fellow being, none would hesitate TO APP


ply that epithet. But to him also who re,
ewes the appellation of Benevolent" !"
ms term is likewise applicable. Ills to
crafty his own feelings. that the former re-
ases to give aught to the wants OF another,
md it is assuredly from the same motive
mat the latter is prompted to relieve them.
ie' perhaps the Benevolent, Zone may say)
toes not always act to please himself. There
lfe some who are ruled by feeling. These
VINO have naturally sensibility' of heart
VIII have hand "open as day to melting
MARTY" From the exercise OF such feel
.ss they derive their own pleasure. as well
sas've relief to others. They therefore act
"Om selfish motive. But those who have
@ @rOt this sensibility to another's suff, ring,
We we cold, the Indifferent, may be as active In
@e discharge of these duties as one OF more
''sssceptibility. They therefore act from
,'nse OF duty alone. and in them it becomes
virtue, Yet they are still governed oy
A.. S.: same principle-in the consciousness O


%a,ns Sa we'll they have their reward; without


"a "1'cn recompence they would not have act


n. ihus they too are selfish. Friendship


nUueh 1t be Of the 'purest kind, is subjected


n f1trA n

began to examine more attentively the tca-
lures of those with whom | had any inter
course. The wrongs that had received, or
seen others receive, made me for time al
most misanthropical, and put an ice-band
round my heart, to keep it fromal sympathy.
But there were still some--or rather, there
was oue--whose smiles could thaw the bar
rier had raised, and again call up the boyish
warmth within me. Henricttc was like the
last dream of youth, and when she was lost
to ne, awokc to grief and-manhood.
cannot describe what felt for her, my soul
has not a tongue, or would do it,. Mine was
love that grew almost from infancy, ere /
had learned to


-"Make my heart grave, and in it bury


deep


Its youth and beautiful feelings"


Now can only remember that felt pas
sinn, aud felt it strongly, hut the different
grades Of sensation which then experience
ed, are lost to me forever, or if at times
am able to recall them, they do not come
freshly back upon me, but indistinctly and
confusedly stealing across my memory,
"Fantly, as does an i'll Remembered dream"
Even in manhood have sometimes been
thrown of my guard by Kind expression
of countenancc, and placed in 1t the implicit
confidence Of younger and better age; but
on these occasions have often had to repent
of my sudden and unquestioning ttith. a.
| bout four years ago, | wandered with some
friends on the Continent, and stopped to re-
fresh at a little village inn: the landlord was
ont, but his wife looked wildly and almost
fcart4lly at US, and spoke III very incohe-
rent manner. There was little boy appar-
ently of about six years If age N a corner OF
the room, whose ccuntenance struck me az
possessing the most beautiful expression
mad ever beheld in a child. By degrees ne
crouched towards US, antI in a whisper told
US that his mother Was suffering under men
tai c"rsnge mcnt; which had been partly oc-
casioned by the ill-treatment Of his father
who stili bc,t her cruelty at times. The art
less manner in which the CHILD spoke Of it,
mothers wrongs, interested us strongly, and
We gave him few peces OF silver OIL leav-
ing Tie house. The day after this. we made
some INQUIRIES, aud fouad that tho boy had
/ spoken the truth with regard to the conduct
Of his father but omitted to state that his
own infant hands had also been raised against
His parent in her hclplessness. 1t was d
bitter pang to me when / thought the child
had reached his very mAnIiood in crime, and
seemed as If he had imbibed hypocrisy and
guilt evcn from his birth. 1t set aside the,
CRY in which l had long indu'ged, ant
weakened my confidence in others, 1t wa:
like finding venon in a spring blossom.
began to doubt whether had myself beer
quite so innocent in childhood as had i'm
agined, for | found that my suspicious OF the
world had robbed me Of many very many
! of INV sweetest feelings: and | almost ian
ced that some drcam had given rise TO thu
idea, and that memory had preserved it
OH that my mind could go back again to it


cight-year-old imaglnings On that my
heart could revert to the Juvenile affection


and innocent associations Of my youth!----


What have since learned that Can at al


compensate for their loss Inc man ma


added little to the child's stock of genera


knowledge, but the biissfui feelings and th


happiness Of the child arc lost to the man for
ever,

full articles.headline:
From the Connecticut Mirror.
~ THE DEATH or AN OLD MAN.
full articles.article:
on THE DEAi IL VI AN VIZ MAN
Attempted Jor The muyie ef Rossean's Dream
Young he left thee--poor he left thee,
sad he left thee, Emerald Isle
when expressions cloud bcreft thee
OF thy last and saddcst smile
Here he came, but ireland ever


warm'd his heart and iilId h's thought
Wandering son Of Erin never


Sought lbs heart and found il not
Fast by Liifeys lovely borders,


Broad of wave, and darkly deep,
Fast BY Lcixlp's lcaping waters,


Parents, friends, aud kindred sleep,
Here he dwelt, and all around him


Blest his warm and honest heart
Here he died as first we found him,


Free from guile and void Of art.
Touchd but now with deaths cold finger,
Here lie walks with us no more
But If spirits ever linger,


His viii haunt the Lificy shore.

full articles.headline:
From tho European Magazine.
LOST rEEI.INGS.
full articles.article:
AsI become older grow conscious that
some feeling of my youth is lost; that some
cherished tie is dissolved. and thai change
has taken place in my passions and affections.
am sorry that it is So for the chahse mas
been an unhappy one. lnstead OF the hopes
Thoughts (surely may call them seq OF
boyhood, have g4iued nothing now but the
knowledge that they were delusive--atd
have parted with the anticipation Of happ-
ness, for the gloomy certainty OF srlet. oh.
there i. nothing like the imaginary ioys Ct
boyhoodl They arc the blossoms oE e%is"
tencc which but too seldom ripen into How
ers. Time, as it roll heavily on, breathes
codly over their passing swcetncss--iliInp
ling with the world Injuries their freshness
and their beauty--thc misery OF others talis
| like blight upon them; manhood kiiis tnem.
Day by day, some leaf falls witnercd from
the stem of hope, and then comes bitterness
Of soul, with fear Of future Ills, and sad but
vain regrets for past pleasures. Nhat weu'a
not give to wander, as used 70 "ahue''
bv that hill which seemed placed by tue
! hard of nature, that man mlBht stahu upon
| its summit, and gaze on Paradise. bue
must have back my boy-teelings, ana see ''a-
ture as then saw her--w1en could LOOK III
her fair face, with heart as pure as the IN
nocent flowers in her lap. here must ne
an echo in my breast to the song OF the larKs
/ those children of the sun--and the scrch
Iity within, which once wed with the trafquA'
surface of that little river which lay oefore
me sleeping in the green arms ol summer
| must have my day-dreams OF fe1i@ity' l
must have back those whom loycd--!oved
with bows warm fcelngs--.and whom in
I ,boI /
I have him who was part of my own heart
} for felt as if a portion OF 1t died whch ne
I was taken from me.


! Without these by-gonc feelings and lost
objects, that scene would be desert, hap
pness, am convinced, is theory OF youth
which manhood seldom practises; Tor re-
member, as if it were yesterday, how my
heart opened to a sense of it. Sorrow was
name then, but pleasure reality. MY MIND
gradually awakened from its dream-and
age, which is truth, reversed them. trust
ed all. and thought no harm OF single ilv-
ing being; for was then, as my frichd Ciare
beautifully expresses it


"Emparadiscd in ignorance of sin"
! loved every one, ard seemed to think that
| there was but one heart which beat for all
mankind. ] knew nothing of conflicting IN
terests. Of friendships exchanged, OF love
unreouited. The whole world seemed like
garden. and the human race Ike movers
I could not then distinguish the weeds that
Grew amongst them. Oh! would that it were
so still Would that could lock upon the
Young as brothers and sisters--on the ageei
as parents, as then did! Would that co"ld
! banish the remembrance of injuries as easl
w as have buried thc resentment they al
I first awakened within me, ami be again the
happy unsuspecting boy | w4s' hut ne"
scenes have opened upon me, ana intercoufSs
with the world has made me suspicious.
cannot put my faith in every smiling iace a
T once could; nor trust TO tones, although
thew seem soft as nightingale or woman = iit
could utter. Some, whom J have thought
nv friends, have shrunk from nc


-"As from stream in winter


o.bsrs who were somewhat older than my
self. but who had appeared to love me as
lovrd them. and that was fervently,) and oe
came sooner initiated into the opiniens OF SO


c,ctv. despised me for my innocence. th'


srcen and undisguised feelings OF youth were


thought OF with contempt by the man. ne
seemed ashamed that they had ever iei


them. and confoundes in their mature i"'as
nations ignorance Of ill'' with ignorance
v;rtue. | saw those--and those. VINO wef'
6 bonnd to me BY the strongest TIES iorsaA
|, m. in nv need. Still continued to THINK


we'll of human nature as could, but the con


Science of the boy was shaken, and the eau
ion Of the man succeeded it. ] mingled IN SO
: ....h the dread Of being deceived, an

4 young woman of good education, aHa-
bic disposition and pleasing manners. was
seduced from the path OF virtue and inno-
cence, by the promise Of immediate mar
riage from her pertlduus lover. She bore
her fate sometime with tortitude and rcsig-
nation; but at length, becoming neglected
by her relatives and left dependent on the
charity of an unfeeling world, she resigned
herself to despair, and determined to end
her life by poison. AS she stretched forth
her hand to grasp the cup containing the IL
quld death, her eye by accident glanced OF
BIBLE which lay open on the table. The
holy book had been opened BY her child
which she then held to her bosom asleep
This sentence attracted her attenton:-
"Danghter, be of good cheer: thv sins are
70 given thee" Hope revived in her breast
and the angel OF mercy stayed the arm o
death!


"Sleep Oil my babe, thy sleep is calm,
Though plow'd onpolluion's breast,
Sleep on AMI sip that bosom balm
Which lulls thy little woes to rest
But all my babe, thou dost not hear
The howng storm, or rattling hail,
Thou do,t not know mothers fear,
No bangs Ike hers thy breast assal
Then sleep thee on-Nor wake again


Fill she who holds thee sleeps in death:
Yes, sleep thee on thy bed of sin


Till heaven demands thy feeting breath.
lcannot weep--though tears would blot,


Forever blot my sins from heav'n;--
cannot pray-O heavy lot!


though angels whispered sins forgiven.
lhtn hall thou rosy poison hail,


forthou can'st calm this bosom's SWELL
Once drank, the world will cease to rail;


Then o! my babe, farewell-farewell!'
She paus'd-for To- before her eye


The book Of hcav'n full open lay,


Which her sweet babe--it knew not Why's


lladl left unclos'd in frolc play.


She real, and while her heart was wrung,


Yetscarccly dared to think ofheaven,


Ayoce pronounced-'twas Mercy's tongue


BE cfgood faith, thou art Jrgiseh!"


aerbabe awoke--a cheerful smile


Ger allts lovely features play'd--


one dash'd the cup--sweet peace returhd,


And deaths upliftcd arm was stay'd.

full articles.headline: MEMORANDA,
full articles.article:
Of some ofhe Signers Of The Declaration Of hide


penaence


Chancellor Wythe, of Virginia; a lawyer;
Judge of the purest morals and deepest
learning, idle and dissipated until thirty
years of age, when he FIRST applied him
slef to law; the preceptor OF Jefferson.
George Reed Of Delaware--an eminent

previously seen, and been familiar with,
some individuals of the paler species Of our
race; but the figure before them was nov
city altogether unimagined--an absurdity
which their constitutional gra yity could not
altogether withstand. They looked again
and again at the rotund lump of humanity
hounderng amid the oozy retirement of
fast receding tide--and as they contrasted
his awkward struggles with their own agil
'ity, his shapeess obesity of frame with their
own Apollonian limbs, considering also the
unheard of fashion of his garments. they
hooted and roared with renewed exertion
Some screamed in prolonged and hideous
cachinnatiens, others cut uncouth somersets
upon the turf or bounded hithcr and yonder
with most antic and gymnastic extravaganza:
in short, such tribe of tom -and Jerry sava-
ges never, till now, figured in the annals OF
comic barbarity.


At length, weared with these roistering
diversions, in more orderly temperament
they approached the object of their mirth,
now almost sulfocated with mre and trcp.
dation. Decming their outrageous capering
the mere signals tor his sacrifice, he buwail
ed the luscious and tempting condition of his
carcase, faneieh fire and faggots, and appre
hended instant martyrdom. His first act, as
they drew nigh, was to discharge from his
right hand the round top hat aforesaid,
which went scaling across the smooth wave
like scared goslin in fish pond. He then
planted his Dorc legs bolt upright in mass
Of soft mud-aIonve whose surface naught
Of his person remained but visage, arms. and
! abdomen. His visters halted upon the more
solid strand: thev could have riddled his hide
with scores of javelins. or pummeled his
prrlcranlum to pummice with paving
stones; but his belhgerent attitude excited
more of curiosity than Indignation. They
wished him no cvil--and as to eating such
an animal. they would sooner by far dine
upon Holsters and pumpkins.


But Derrick waxed resolute, and began,
in his despair, to spatter sundry handtulls
of filth upon and around the copper faced
spectators--whereby they were not a little
scandalized. Presently sturdy youngster
threatened to advance; when Derrick, losing
all manner of philosophy, uttered a tremen-
dous High Dutch oath, distorted his coun-
tenance into its ugliest corrugatlons, pro-
truded the fronts of his jaws 50 as to resem.
BILE the anterior edge of hard shelled clam,
and bowIed for help in a tone Of agony rem
dered doubly dismal by it's chromatic vari-
atoms. Still his principal assailant cortin-
ued to approximate, and coming within
arms length, grapplcd the Hollander' S
yncae that dangled SO formidably over his
expanded shouldcrs-Immediatel the rest
Of the tribe ranged themselves i'll single file
behind their leader, by dint of whose hold
upon Derick's cabbage stalk, they dragged
his unwieldy corporation fairly above high
water mark.


! Here the exhausted victim sunk into a
state of stupor; and, while in this condition,
his uncivl conquerors, with sharp stone


instrument, rudely sawed off the appurte-
nance by which thev had cxtrcarcti him.
and bore away the trophy ia triumph a
/ decd fraught with narrowing perpleMites,
as the sequel may manifest. Seeing them
depart, his fellow -voyagers who had watch
! ed every movement from the ship, sdventur-


ed to despatch boat to his assistance. His


red waistcoat, loomed up from the beach


like an Egyptian brick kiln, served TO de-
signate the point of their destination, which
they soon reached. Silently and eXpedi-
| tiously they conveyed the body OH four oars
to the boat, and thence to the ship. But
| Derrick awoke not, until the vessel, blessed


with propitious gales, reached the little


settlement of New Amsterdam, now 10 the


overgrown city of New York wherein /,


hath become an Object Tor Doctors. and Col
onels, and Majors daily to put forth Large


printed sheets ycleped newspapers.


| However, Mynecr Won Hoogensperg ir


due course of time came to himself aud his
uncle's executors. The latter, on comparing


his appearance with the description con


tanned in the old gentleman's bequest, posi-
lively refused to admit his CLAIMS Ont
prominent accoutrcme1t was missing! lr


vain did the unfortunate Dutchman appea


to his accompanying countrymen, Tor evil
dence that the identical club of hair, now


adtuced, actually belonged to his occiput al
their departure from Rotterdam ; in vaii


did they relate the story Of his cruel excis'


ion--for he could remember nothing thereof


in vain did he pack off messengers, will
bribes and presents, to treat with the isant


savages for the recovery of that instrument


upon which his fortune depended in vair


he swore; he sued in vain. The matter
got into law, and there it hung, as it were
by hair, term after term, until nature sup
piled him with new crop; when ne wa


enabled te snap his fingers at the lawyers
take possession of an immense estate, estab
lish diStiliery as the surest means OF re


venge upon his tawny adventures, marry


live forty years, die without progeny, ant


lie down amongst his ancestors in the gra


mite sepulchre of the Hoogenspergs. 1t ma,


be necessary to add, that the original brusl


in question, was carefully preserved as al
invaluable relic by the Indians and their de
! scendants, through four entire generations


when it was inhumed, together with numer

an apprentice to carpenter in Virginia
self educated to the law; colonel; wound
ed in battle; twice Governor Of Georgia
chief justice; senator of the United States,


George Clymer, of fPennsylvania--a mer-
chant; fond of literature; terse, scnten-
tious writer; an efficient and honored patri.
OF. His biography full and interesting, but
diifuse.


------"Goodness his delight,


Wisdom his wealth, and glory his reward"


Benjamin Rush, as a physician and aB
author omni laude cumulatus; the most cell
ebratcd of the American faculty;-distin-
guished also for his political connexions and
labors.


Matthew Thornton, Of New Hampshire;
successful practitioner of medicine; army
surgeon before the Revolution; president
of the provincial convention; "A judge of the
| Supreme Court: a man of wit and humor;
continued to practice physic while judge
wrote political essays for the newspapers,
and prepared a metaphysical work for pub
ication. after lie was eighty years OF age
died in his eighty ninth year.
William Whipple of New Hampshirs---
originally cabin boy and sailor; captain
at the age of 81; then merchant, gener-
al, who fought with Gates, and elsewhere
arranged the capitulation of Bnrgoyne; a
Judge of the supreme court. "As a sailor"
says his biography. che speedily attained
the highest rank in his profession; as mer-
chant, he was circumspect and industrious;
as congressman. he was firm and fearless;
as commander he was cool and courageous
las judge, he was dignified and impartial;
as member of subordinate public Offices.
he was alert and persevering. He bore all
| A. -. L ,,tI1J and retu


DIR. John Witherspoon, of New Jersey, an
eminent and profound divine. president Of
Nassau Hall College; political writer of
force and talent; a statesman of great infiu-
ence and energy. His biography is ample
and instructive.


Robert Morris, of Pennsylvania; mer-
chant; the unrivallrd financier of the Revo-
luton; the pecuniary soul of the cause. His
biography, like that of others needs COM
preston, but it is interesting and correct.
Abraham Clark, of New Jersey; sur"
veyor; lawyer who gave gratutons coun-
sci.


Francis Lewis, of New York; a merchant
and soldier before the Revolution; very
useful as Il rebel; his fine estate OH Long
/ Island, destroyed by the British, and his
wife carried off prisoner; she died soon af-
ter, from the ill treatment which was expe-
rienced. He was ruined by the part which
he took on the American side-died in the
4 Goth year Of his age.


| John Penn, of North Carolina; uneducat-
ed in early life; became lawyer, and emf
nent, by opslmathy.


| James Wilson, of Pennsylvania, lawyer
of rare capacity, and Of surprising faculties
as a speaker and writer, and efficient polit-
ical essayst; the principal advocate of the
constitution Of 1887, in the Pennsylvania
convention; professor of law, and judge of
the Supreme Court of the United States.-
His biography replete with valuable intor-
nation and political anecdote.


Carter Braxton, of Virginia; planter;-
became a merchant; lost all, and died OF q
broken heart.


John Morton of Pennsylvania; surveyor;
speaker of the General Assembly of Penn
sylvania; "A Judge of the Supreme Court of
the Commonwealth; gave the casting vote
of the Pennsylvania delegation, tor the dec
laration of independence; originally plough
boy


Stephen Hopkins, of Rhede Island; plain
| farmer, surveyor, became speaker of the
| Assembly, chief justice, then Governor of
| Rhode Island, man of superior sense and a
good and successful writer, distinguished
mathematician, and natural philosopher,
CnOupn MS cuuCdtlOb was oil6it, Apa hShN
her of the American Philosophical society.
His signature to the Declaration Is the only
crooked and feeble one. CAS- it indicates"
SAYS his biographer. "a very trcmuleus hand
! in perfect contrast with the bold and prom
inent writing of President Hancock it may
have engendered surmises unfavorable to
the determined spirit of Mr.. Hopkins. We
the erefnre state, for a number OF years pre-
vious he had been afflicted with nervous
Affection, and when he wrote at all, which
was seldom, he was compelled to guide his
right hand with his left"


Thomas M'Kean, of Pennsylvania, a law
yer of great abilities and ardent revolution
asry patriotism, chief justice ofthe Common
wealth, governor, died eishty-three years
old. His biography entirely authentic, and
replenished with instructive details.


James Smith of Pennsylvania. lawyer and
surveyor, remarkable for righteousness and
eccentricity, practised law for upwards oi
GO years, died a nonagenarian. His article
very pleasant.
Thomas Nelson of Virginia. educated ir

lawyer. His biography lis ample, Interest,"
ing and authentic.


William Williams, OF Connecticut, ORR
ginally town clerk, but literally educated
then an upright, benevolent merchant;-
sacrificed the greater part of his gains to the
public service.


Samuel Huntington Of Connecticut--a
mere ploughman until his twenty second
year; afterwards an eminent lawyer; presi-
dent of congress; chief justice of his state,
and Governor. His biography is highly Curl
GUS.


VIM. Floyd. of New York--a farmer;
general; enjoyed large share Of state hon
ors.


George Walton, of Georgia-originally
an apprentice to carpenter in Virginia
self educated to the law; colonel; wound
ed in battle; twice Governor of Georgia
chief justice; senator of the United States.


George Clymer, of fPennsylvania--a mer-
chant; fond of literature; terse, scnten-
tious writer; an efficient and honored patri-
OF. His biography full and interesting, but
diifuse.
